body: yep. `./gradlew clean check` on my laptop is now back to a tolerable 1.5mins

private constructor with apply starts going down the manual `case class` route, so may not be the best choice.

One thing I might suggest however, is adding a `require` into the case class body to make sure all the things that should be lowercase are indeed lowercase, so people who skip the conversions are not caught off guard.
@prat0318  Which storage backend were you running?
cassandra
#835 helped, thank you. Will hope that 5mb will be enough for gzipped data. Now dealing with #832
Anyone can help with this? @adriancole?

Can you post JSON of the trace in question (taken from
/api/v1/trace/your_id_here)?

Do you know what command results in a response of >12s? Ex. can you post a
stack trace? That sounds like a long time.. I suspect we could update it or
punch a hole, but it would be nice to know what is taking so long..
SGTM
@abesto if you're interested in this, lemme know.
But even with that span, the info on the screen is all over the place, top says Total Spans 3, but under Expand buttons is says `example - x3` and `example2 - x1`
Totally. Licensing is something I'm recently very interested in; if no-one picks it up, I'll have a look this weekend.

so a span can be sent in parts, but by query time, they should be merged. That's a feature, not a bug.

The UI says that 3 spans include the service "example" and 2 include the service "example2", which seems to match the json. These are buttons that will select spans that include that service.

It is well known that the UI isn't intuitive, but I don't see a bug here.. do you?
IMHO, these [service xN] buttons and other confusing clutter on the screen might be better off deleted

The build is blowing up, guessing something around java8. I can help debug this later, if the cause isn't obvious.

Besides that, I'm happy with helping to support this code. I'd like some clarity on the naming choices, but otherwise LGTM

I have built it on Mac with

```
$ java -version
java version "1.8.0_45"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_45-b14)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.45-b02, mixed mode)
```

The CI job runs with "1.8.0_31", maybe that's the reason for compiler failure. Can we bump java version in CI?

Actually, maybe the counts are correct if interpreted as "how many spans mention service X". However, the bug wasn't about that, it was about the search results, where it said the trace has 4 spans. It has 4 records in the db, that's true, but only 3 spans, with 3 unique span IDs. As for buttons on details page, I think they are useful, as they control highlighting of the spans. If I searched for a service and that service turns out to be right in the middle of a span 20-levels deep, then being able to highlight it is a nice touch.
Cool. thanks for clarifying the bug! I think I can squash this one.

appears to have a recent JDK, now.

```
$ java -Xmx32m -version
java version "1.8.0_66"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_66-b17)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.66-b17, mixed mode)
```
mind squashing this into a single commit when you rebase on top of the travis JDK bump?
I know you know how, but I like pasting this.. http://rebaseandsqua.sh/ :)
I'll cherry-pick this in

closed via https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/commit/9603ca81f22d1b8e8ba17b9f0663603184d154dd

Thanks tons!
nice work @yurishkuro
LGTM, but I would really like to understand and ideally remove the restriction `traceId == spanId` for root spans.
ps fwiw I would like to understand traceid=spanid, too
@theatrus @eirslett @kristofa anybody have any insight (or memory) about this?
PS parked the root span.id=traceid here: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/849

Food for thought: [dapper](http://static.googleusercontent.com/media/research.google.com/en//pubs/archive/36356.pdf) doesn't seem to imply a span.id=traceid restriction:

> Spans created without a parent id are known as root spans. All spans associated with a specific trace also share a common trace id.

A bit of a guess, but the traceid=spanid may have nothing to do with dapper, and more about the predecessor to the predecessor of zipkin: https://github.com/twitter/finagle/commit/e00c91709c1be6710d4aee102139b12cb1f837d2#diff-50e70bbc12edca0f2c7be3f34b53d88aR32

Also, seems htrace already have to set traceid differently, as their ids are 128bit! https://github.com/apache/incubator-htrace/blob/master/htrace-zipkin/src/main/java/org/apache/htrace/zipkin/HTraceToZipkinConverter.java#L112

I did a quick look through zipkin's scala code the only thing that seems impacted by this might be smoked out via DependencyStoreSpec. For instrumentation, probably just want to make sure none of core tracers indicate root span via parent_id=0 (vs null) or parent_id=trace_id
NEXT STEP: let others speak up about this

+1 for removing this restriction! That also lets us encode information in the span IDs (like where in the call tree the span originates from)
I'm +1 on this, too. I'll raise a PR with some test clarifications to support this
c\* dependency tests weren't actually running. fixed that and backfilled tests to ensure we don't rely on this convention. https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/851

+1

So despite the old docs/comments, doesn't seem like there was any actual code that required traceId==spanId for root span?
Nope! no code change needed, so yeah glad about that.
CC @mstine @adriancole

Thanks. good start. I suspected there'd be a crapload of licenses (because crapload of dependencies).

I think it is most important to know the licenses "per binary" like, collector, web, query.

Do you mind running this and place the example html output in a comment, image a pastebin? That will lower the barrier to review for folks who don't have gradle setup. (Also, you could raise this as a openzipkin branch, too)

We should be able to do per subproject (=== per binary) simply, I'll give it a go today.

I've added the license reports for review, easy way to check: http://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/abesto/zipkin/blob/license-check/build/reports/license/license-dependency.html
I'll raise a pull request to switch out mysql driver for mariadb. There's an exception to the GPL clause, but still unnecessarily scary: https://www.mysql.com/about/legal/licensing/foss-exception/
SGTM. In the meanwhile, the check is now run separately for the collector, query and web services, as well as for the root project, just in case.
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/853 wrt killing the GPL dep
corresponding issue in zipkin-java: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/pull/44
ps #853 trims SQL databases to a more relevant list, namely drivers you can configure OOB

Closing this issue a we are removing H2 from the default list. Since we don't run tests or allow docker configuration, H2 may already be broken without us knowing: #853

In the near future, we will release an alternative to anorm, jOOQ, in the [java project](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/blob/master/zipkin-java-jdbc). If there's enough interest to contribute docs and tests for other databases, we can always pick this back up.

Closing this issue a we are removing PostgreSQL from the default list. Since we don't run tests or allow docker configuration, PostgreSQL may already be broken without us knowing: #853

In the near future, we will release an alternative to anorm, jOOQ, in the [java project](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-java/blob/master/zipkin-java-jdbc). If there's enough interest to contribute docs and tests for other databases, we can always pick this back up.

UPDATE: did a lot of research and backfilling code docs, which will be where most of the rest docs are harvested from. Anyone needing insight into the model before this issue closes can look here: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-thrift/src/main/thrift/com/twitter/zipkin/zipkinCore.thrift#L272

good point. are you running a flag that prevents auto-addition perhaps?
No, auto-addition not disabled in any way.

ex. if you are using docker-containers, or the -service packages as an entrypoint (ex. `query-cassandra.scala`), then `CASSANDRA_ENSURE_SCHEMA` env is used, which defaults to true.

If you have a custom build, then the flag `zipkin.store.cassandra.ensureSchema` defaults to false. How are you running?

I'm running custom-built jars using https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-query-service/config/query-cassandra.scala 
In that case what value will be assigned to zipkin.store.cassandra.ensureSchema?

it should default to true.. what's weird is that this implies `CREATE
TABLE IF NOT EXISTS zipkin.span_duration_index...` didn't work? which
doesn't make immediate sense to me.

ex. ensureExists in Repository.java isn't conditional on anything
except for the flag, so the DDL should execute top-to-bottom.

by should I mean it does default to true, due to this line:
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-query-service/config/query-cassandra.scala#L27

ps hold on this one if you can :) there's a schema adjustment for that
table coming!
Sounds fine to me, as long as we make it obvious in the code and DDL that these are millisecond granularity as opposed to micros.
After checking scala config, noticed that it lacks line you pointed. That's the case, thank you.
whew! Thanks for reporting back.. was a bit worried!

I think we should apply this globally. ex change QueryRequest and the HTTP api to millis, so it is consistent. The logic is sound, and a change like this is better to do before we document the HTTP api.
Whackamole is down, GPL removed from the whitelist :fireworks: The license listing is also updated.
sgtm

Moving a conversation here from a changed / removed line: there's a couple of dependencies with no license specified.
- Some of these are Zipkin projects; for those, this is a good opportunity to add license information to the POM files (https://github.com/hierynomus/license-gradle-plugin/blob/master/src/main/groovy/nl/javadude/gradle/plugins/license/LicenseResolver.groovy#L192 shows that's what the plugin uses, as opposed to LICENSES files or some other heuristic)
- The rest are external dependencies, where we can track down licenses where available and tell the plugin about those explicitly in the build definition of Zipkin, as shown in https://github.com/hierynomus/license-gradle-plugin#license-reporting

I propose we break these out into two separate issues.
sgtm. Let's merge this when you're ready.
New issues created, commits squashed, reports removed. Ready for final review and merge.

nice. :shipit:
ps 1.25.0 adjusts the aforementioned table. hot off the press
Should we close this as fixed by my PR?
Fixed #857

-1 (first time ever in zipkin)

I don't like this for a number of reasons:
- The syntax is parsed and validated on the server side. This is an unnecessary round trip.
- Web developers now need to learn scala to troubleshoot this parameter.
- Alternative implementations of the query api now need to be compatible with scala duration parsing
- It is a well-understood goal to move zipkin-web towards a pure-js app, and this is the opposite

I'd suggest using moments.js or some other javascript library instead.
@danchia @yurishkuro @eirslett @nikhil2406 @gneokleo @synk Fishing for those who've touched flight components before :) Do any of you have some cycles to try this?
Hi, any update on this?

so 12 seconds is a very long time. do you have some network problem where
it is normal for 12 seconds is normal? How do you know 13 seconds or 30
seconds would improve things? Or are you just interested in experimenting
why you are having severe connectivity problems.

Maybe we should fallback to a non-error state, like empty result, when this
occurs?

I want to avoid opening new flags for every one of the boundless scenarios
one could encounter. Reason is that our configuration story is quite bad
(unlike zipkin-java where it is quite easy to do this). Ex we have a lot of
work and if you find that 12 seconds or 30 seconds you still have a connect
timeout, then that work stays in the codebase..

I do think we need to consider how to do "pass-through" config to a driver.
This sort of pass-through was attempted in HTrace, for example in kafka
transport
https://github.com/apache/incubator-htrace/blob/master/htrace-zipkin/README.md

@michaelsembwever @yurishkuro do you have any ideas on this topic? Do you
think 12s timeout is unreasonably short? Should we add a fallback to empty
on this?

We had an issue once that was manifesting in very long query latencies. It turned out to be due to the driver directing some queries to nodes in another data center. Solved by `DCAwareRoundRobinPolicy`:

```
  // on Mac the default data center name in Cassandra is 'datacenter1'
  val dataCenter  = flag[String] ("datacenter", "data center name used by DC-aware load balancing policy, required.")

  override def createClusterBuilder(): Cluster.Builder = {
    val dc = dataCenter.apply()
    val lbPolicy = new TokenAwarePolicy(new LatencyAwarePolicy.Builder(new DCAwareRoundRobinPolicy(dc)).build())
    super.createClusterBuilder()
      .withLoadBalancingPolicy(lbPolicy)
      .withQueryOptions(new QueryOptions().setConsistencyLevel(ConsistencyLevel.LOCAL_ONE))
  }
```

I think it would make sense to make this a default setting in zipkin.

Specifically on this issue, I don't think 12s is a reasonable timeout if Cassandra is operating normally, it either indicates misconfigured cluster, or bad query pattern (too much data requested?)

It's actually not connectivity issue, all servers hosted inside vpc and networking is not a problem. 
This error arises only if there is large amount of data to fetch from cassandra (large traces with thousands of spans), and cassandra requires more than 12 seconds to provide it. It matter of cassandra performance (though, it hosted on r3.xlarge with ssd disks).
Now we have ~15Gb of data daily, and zipkin becomes unusable after 1-2 days.
I guess more people will require that timeout to be configurable in future.

DCAwareRoundRobinPolicy shouldn't be the issue, since there is single cassandra instance.

Sorry, I got distracted by the NoHostAvailableException in the log eventhough you mentioned the OperationTimedOutException underneath it. What parameter are you looking for specifically (just in case)?

It shouldn't take 12s to retrieve 10 traces (based on your log), especially in recent implementations. Ex. we have a default lookback parameter now, which you can use to reduce how far queries look back. In other words, if it is scanning days of data to get 10 traces, that sounds like a bug. What version are you running?

IIRC, twitter kept 3 days of trace data (at some point it was high as 7). Uber is 2d? There are certainly going to be limits. ~15Gb/day is an interesting figure. Do you know how many traces/day that turns into?

Currently running 1.25.1-SNAPSHOT with cassandra 2.0.17.
We are trying to keep 7d of data (afair, same default for lookback).
Roughly, it's 16 000 000 traces per day.

@drax68 thanks for bearing with us.. do you mind turning debug logging on for org.twitter.zipkin.storage.cassandra.Repository ? It will emit which queries passed before blowing up. Ex. it would be nice to know if the blowup happened fetching ids or something else. A more recent stack trace will probably say most of that (the one in your log says 1.23.2-SNAPSHOT)
ps feel free to join gitter to discuss https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin I really think there's a solvable problem here.
ps looks like this is the setting in question: http://docs.datastax.com/en/drivers/java/2.0/com/datastax/driver/core/SocketOptions.html#setReadTimeoutMillis-int-
